Posts.Title: Really Rough Day rinneron sarajaneevans

Posts.Content: Apr 30, 2013 10:59AM sarajaneevans wrote: I had the first of three scheduled consultations yesterday-Yesterdays  surgeon did not break the path report down for us like I had hoped she would, so I still don't know what any of it means-- she basically said the same thing as my primary, except my primary said the right breast was ok- which the surgeon says it is not-- it is precancerous, so the surgeon said she will do a lumpectomy of both breasts- She also said the cancer is stage 1 or 2 but they won't really know anything for sure until they do the surgery-which totally makes sense to me--so even with the path report we are still just guessing?? Anyway for reasons I list, I think I have made up my mind that the surgeon I am seeing tomorrow will be the one I choose- I feel very blessed that my sis in law works in the surgery center where my surgery will be done- I gave her the names of the two surgeons I was referred to. She checked with the surgical nurses and was told hands down the surgeon I see tomorrow is the best,two of the nurses have had breast cancer and he was their surgeon. Of all three I scheduled appointments with his office was the only one who requested my breast records be faxed to them, so he could familiarize hmself with my history before the appointment, which is comforting to me- I also like the fact that if you call his office and need to speak to him directly you are given his contact number-it makes me feel that if an emergency situation arises, his door is open to me- that makes me feel safe...the fact that the surgical nurses applaud him pretty much made my decsion for me. I will see him tomorrow so keeping my fingers crossed... If you think I am off my rocker for the choices I am making please holler at me-- it seems I get more confused with each day- the one thing the surgeon said to us is ITS CURABLE.. those are MAGIC  words... I just have this very dense fog bank living where my brains once did, so it feels anyway, makes it hard to see to what is really there ya know.... Thank you all for everything you do in here... You are all amazing women- God bless each of you..
Posts.Title: How to choose surgeon? Just diagnosed Caswellat sarajaneevans

Posts.Content: Mar 9, 2014 03:51PM sarajaneevans wrote: Baby granddaughters are the best-I have one who shares this birthday with yours(mine is 17 now)- I agree with Bestbird-no throwing in the towel until other avenues have been explored-that baby needs to get to know her grandma..many prayers and positive rays- keep the faith-
Posts.Title: How did I end up here? SAMayoFL stagefree

Posts.Content: May 3, 2013 06:54AM sarajaneevans wrote: I don't know how to advise you -but I can share my experience with you- I have been diagnosed with IDLC-I get yearly mamos-up to this year they have been clean-I felt a quite large lump before this years mamo for about a month prior- one day it was not there the next it was- what I have learned going through my process is that this mass/tumor does not show up on a mamo until it is large enough to be felt on self examination-my surgeon said in all likely hood it has been progressing  for 2- 3 years-still, as large as mine is, it is very difficult to read on the mamo-Had I not been able to feel it this year, it would have gone undetected again- I'm pretty new here- but hopefully some of the other more experienced BC posters can advise you- Prayers and positive rays only for you-
Posts.Title: Lump felt but not seen on mammo or ultrasound... GoldenGirls sarajaneevans

Posts.Content: Apr 28, 2013 01:34PM sarajaneevans wrote: Thank you so much Charz..I have read and re-read your response over and over, and it just now starting to sink in- I am overwhlemed by all the different diagnosis and all the woman who have been touched by this monster-I read and then I panic so I have to leave-- but I also realize I have to find out everything I can too--so I am rather scattered -come for air take deep breaths and come back down again-- you are all amazing women-I very much appreciate your post-thanks again...

I don't know what is going to happen with me in the future but any decision I make with regards to treatment will be my business-I can see AJ wanting to do whatever she needs to do to insure that she is around to raise her children- what I don't get is why anyone really cares about the decisons she makes that effect her, except maybe her family members.

Posts.Content: May 28, 2013 09:46PM - edited May 30, 2013 09:33AM by sarajaneevans The point I am trying to make is that what AJ does with her body, the decisions she has made are no ones business- unless her actions affect you personally the decisions she makes are nobodys business- I have read posts condeming her over and over again for the choice she made- the choice she made in my opinion is nobodys busiiness-it is her body, her life and if she wants to become a quadruple amputee to ensure that she is around to watch her children grow up it is nobodys business. I think it is very sad that b/c she is a celebrity all of a sudden it is a big deal b/c of who she is-her life is more important than all the thousands who fight this disease every day- granted that is not her fault, but the same people who helped put her on that pedestal are some of the same ones who are throwing rocks at her today for making the decision she did.. I don't have to be afflicted with a disease or know someone who is to see the benefit of helping where I can- I volunteer for Relay for Life- I volunteer for many causes b/c I see the need and I want to help-
Posts.Title: Angelina Jolie's prophylactic surgery JoanQuilts SusansGarden

Posts.Content: May 28, 2013 12:11PM sarajaneevans wrote: @MelissaDallas I'm just saying just b/c she is a celebrity- doesn't make her any more special than the rest of us. At the end of the day she is no different- just b/c she is AJ NOW people will sit up and take notice? Where has her concern for BC been in the past-it just seems to me that now that she has made the decision to have her breasts removed,its suddenly a big deal? It is no bigger deal to me that it is AJ than it is for all the thousands of other women going through it. If she were to come here and get down in the trenches with the rest of us, I would feel differently, but, oh wait, she is AJ after all.

All the hullabaloo over the choice she made- the point for me, is that it is her business to do what she feels is best for her body,her life, her family- her choices are none of my business.

Posts.Content: May 27, 2013 08:00PM - edited May 27, 2013 08:04PM by sarajaneevans Hi Sparky, You sound just like me two weeks ago-I had my consultation with the surgeon on my birthday-I was so hoping to get a full explanation of the pathology report- the numbers and abbreviations meant nothing to me and pretty much they still don't as what he said to me is. I won't know what we are dealing with until I get in there-- My final path appointment was last Thursday and had to be rescheduled as the surgeon was detained in surgery,so tomorrow we are scheduled at 2:30. l I could not make any sense of my initial path report except the diagnosis-the rest was greek to me. There is just so much to digest- we have to start somewhere and this is a pretty good place I have discoverfed. I still don't know what all the abbreviations are and quite frankly I get a bit terrified reading many of these posts-but what is they say- Knowledge is power-just make sure if you have to have a sentinel node dye injection procedure seek information here about it before hand. Good luck to you-

Posts.Content: Jun 17, 2013 05:55PM sarajaneevans wrote: @BeHereNow- were you able to by-pass radiation? if so, congratulations(: on that -- Is tamoxifen the five year pill and is it considered chemo as well? And so you lost your hair during chemo and things in that ares are not looking much better with this pill? My head is swimming.. I hope to get a definite treatment plan on Friday. I have a Pet scan on Wednesday and the results from that along with my pathology will determine what my treatment will be exactly-- I am trying to educate myself but it is not easy without all the facts...I am gaining new knowledge on this site from all of you every day..just not sure what to do with it just yet-- I'm trying to build an arsenal of tips and such that will help alog the way... You are all so brave!!!  My prayers and positive rays are with each and every one of you going through the recovery trials of this monster disease...
Posts.Title: April 2013 Chemo Group BeHereNow 6cats

Posts.Content: Jun 18, 2013 03:15AM sarajaneevans wrote: 6cats, Thanks so much for the good information AND it does help- I have no intention of doing any of the things she is suggesting. I  appreciate her concern and wish I knew how to respond t her, but I don't.. so I read and tell her I found the article interesting. I can only deal with one thing at a time and right now that is my oncologist, the expert-I would never do anything or take anything without asking him first- I have total trust in him.  Most of the things I am researching are, things like water, what is the best water to drink, least amount of additives, that sort of thing-kicked all the sugar out of the house today- I'm having my acrylic nails taken off --I do not want anything that is not natural around me for the time being..I'll just go nubby nailed...getting products that will help with oral hygiene and hopefully ward off the mouth sores- pretty much anything that I can find that might lessen SE of the chemo.I know I  can't control the SE of Chemo or the cancer but if I can lessen some of the SE with diet then I am all in.. I learned on here about the glutamine, sipping it before during and after the chemo to help with mouth sores..this is the kind of information I am looking for. I know what helps some of us will not help others with their battle. I think I am getting overfreaky about not having anything in the house that is not natural..

Posts.Title: In shock bennymuffins websister

Posts.Content: Aug 2, 2013 09:26PM sarajaneevans wrote: My first treatment I had a terrible headache too. My onc nurse said it was from the zofran- the next treatment they gave a new nausea med, Kytril- no headache at all. She also advised me to take 2 tylenol and 1 benadryl to help me sleep- she said it would help, and it sure did.  I have my 3rd of 6 infusions next Tuesday. I am feeling pretty good this time around, actually. I am nervous about this one b/c I have read the treatments are cumulative and that three is a bad one.  The one really bad thig for me is that everything tastes like I took a big swig out of a bottle of alcohol and I don't mean liquor- rubbing. The taste never goes away- the only things I have found that taste like they should are 'drum roll' Chocolate and Chocolate Milk.  I have been very blessed not to experience many of the SE I read about on this site-the last one I had a general feeling of just not being well from the get go- that lasted about a week -longer than the first time but not as brutal and to be pefectly honest I can't remember too much about either of them now.  My prayers and good thoughts are with all of you as your fight continues (((huggs)))

Posts.Content: Jul 15, 2013 12:02PM - edited Jul 15, 2013 12:03PM by sarajaneevans I am SO SORRY for your loss- there isn't anything much worse than losing a beloved and faithful companion 0:):): I know your pain and grieve with you ): I believe that we will all be reuinted one day with all of our furry kids who have gone before us.. Rainbow Bridge Poem; You may know it-if not, may it bring you and your family some comfort... Rainbow Bridge: Just this side of heaven is a place called Rainbow Bridge. When an animal dies that has been especially close to someone here, that pet goes to Rainbow Bridge. There are meadows and hills for all of our special friends so they can run and play together. There is plenty of food, water and sunshine, and our friends are warm and comfortable. All the animals who had been ill and old are restored to health and vigor. Those who were hurt or maimed are made whole and strong again, just as we remember them in our dreams of days and times gone by. The animals are happy and content, except for one small thing; they each miss someone very special to them, who had to be left behind. They all run and play together, but the day comes when one suddenly stops and looks into the distance. His bright eyes are intent. His eager body quivers. Suddenly he begins to run from the group, flying over the green grass, his legs carrying him faster and faster. You have been spotted, and when you and your special friend finally meet, you cling together in joyous reunion, never to be parted again. The happy kisses rain upon your face; your hands again caress the beloved head, and you look once more into the trusting eyes of your pet, so long gone from your life but never absent from your heart. Then you cross Rainbow Bridge together.... Author unknown...

Posts.Title: Has anyone heard from Lisa/Chainsawz? nancyh Naniam

Posts.Content: Aug 2, 2013 03:01PM - edited Aug 3, 2013 12:26AM by sarajaneevans Re: Wigs... I went to what was touted as a professional wig store- paid $350 for a wig that is CRAP- the head needs to be measured so you can get the right size I discovered after the fact, and while doing some research- the store should well have done this for me if they are so professional. They will not refund or exchange, say they have a no exchange, no refund policy when I called them,-signs are posted in the their shop,they said. I asked if it ever occurred to them to them they they are dealing with people undergoing treatment who are most likely not feeling their best and might not see their little signs that are posted- Perhaps if customer satisfaction is a priority they might think about 'VERBALIZING' this policy to their customer while customer before the sale is finalized! Live and learn..... I purchased another wig online at tlc for $50 -I absolutely love it! and you can exchange it and get a refund if not totally satisfied. The first time I wore it out, I felt normal. I told my husband, "People are staring at me and thinking one of two things either, 1. That lady has one fine looking hairdo...................... or 2. Who does that old hag think she is fooling with that wig?  LOL, LOL LOL..I chose number 1 (:" More expensive in this case was not better and at this price I can have a few more (: http://www.tlcdirect.org/Default.aspx

Posts.Content: Jun 10, 2013 05:03PM sarajaneevans wrote: I had my second lumpectomy on June 7th to widen margins, and the port for chemo was installed or however you describe it-- See the oncologist the 14th for the first time and hopefully to get an explanation of the final pathology and what it all means in terms of treatment- I try to read your posts here so I can get an education on what to expect but I just find myself getting lightheaded and ready to pass out when I do-- anyone else experience this? I want to know what to expect so I can be somewhat prepared-but this little voice inside me says, you'll be fine, you don't need to know ahead of time -it will be different for you- I know that little voice is like the biggest liar in my life at the moment-sometimes I feel like little pieces of the puzzle are being kept from me- I know this is nothing more than my own paranoia.. Thanks to you all for sharing and posting your experiences here..
Posts.Title: April 2013 Chemo Group BeHereNow 6cats

Posts.Content: Jun 10, 2013 10:42PM - edited Jun 11, 2013 12:35AM by sarajaneevans Hi MsPharoah, Thanks so much for the response- I am trying really hard not to assume anything- I realize we are all differnt and no two treatments or reactions will be the same- Thanks for all the great tips- I am making a "what IF folder' I will copy your response and ad it to my folder- I think you can  never be too prepared for the what if's b/c none of us know what is on down the road-easier to have these tips in a binder instead of trying to go back and remember where you saw them...I guess these are all things I will discover when I see the oncologist on Friday- how they decide what kind of chemo, how much and how often.... Are these all things you learned after you started your chemo? Fortunately my kids are all grown, just my DH and my little four leggers@home- grown kids have been very good about coming over and seeing that we have meals cooked and laundry is done, so that part of this is not a worry to me right now- I just had another big gulp- My surgeon is going out of the country for a few weeks-I guess by the time you see the oncologist you don't need the surgeon anymore? I worry I will need him and he will be unavailable..

I have yet to meet him so don't really know too much yet about my diagnosis and nothing about the treatment- only that I am going to have chemo... Anyway,thanks for thie tips..I am taking  notes   You are all amazing women!!!
Posts.Title: April 2013 Chemo Group BeHereNow 6cats

Posts.Content: Jul 3, 2013 04:28PM sarajaneevans wrote: AmyQ-WOW, Congratulations to you, pinch,pinch,pinch, must feel like you got a very early Christmas present... SE from my first chemo kicked in three days post treatment- had me pretty much down for 3 days with the Mac Truck syndrome- Had my first N injection yesterday due to low WBC-so far no SE from that- have a bit of a sore throat this morning-I am thinking I better call and report that to my oncologist-just to be on the safe side,especially with the long weekend approaching. So far, no hair fall out- I am expecting that around 10 July, if it seems to happen on day 14 following first chemo, but then again I not looking that hard so maybe I won't find it. I saw my surgeon yesterday as well about the 'sloshing boob noise' that accompanies me when I walk- he confirmed it is a seroma, and said he could drain it or whatever the terminolgy is, I opted to let it do its thing and absorb-so long as it is not painful or feverish he agreed that is the best choice. Best of Luck to each of you as your individual battle continues. Happy Independence Day everyone
